title: Glock Sight Press
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Press for adjusting the rear sight on Glock Safe Action Pistols. An inexpensive alternative to the commercially available aluminum and steel sight installation/adjustment tools.

This is a lightweight press for adjusting (or installing) rear sights on a Glock Safe Action Pistol. I designed it based on measurements for a Glock 17, though I believe the rear slide dimensions are consistent enough through the rest of the models, that it should work with them as well.
A 3" long 1/4-20 screw gets epoxied into the handle. There is a void in the handle to allow the epoxy plenty of mechanical grip against the shape. A 1/4-20 nut fits inside the body. Depending on the size head on the screw you use, you may want to adjust the diameter of the hole in the handle accordingly.
The slide is reversible, so it can be used with Glock sights which have angled sides, or with aftermarket sights with vertical sides. 
I printed the body and handle with 10% infil. It feels solid but is quite lightweight (especially compared to a traditional aluminum sight press). Because the force of the screw is concentrated on the surface at the bottom of the hole in the slide, I think it's worth printing the slide separately as a solid object. I've uploaded an stl of all three parts, as well as separate files to allow the slide to be printed solid.
Additionally, dropping a small washer or metal disk into the hole in the slide should improve its durability (or just print a new one if/when it wears out).
This is a push-only sight press, and must be slid onto the receiver with the handle on the opposite side to move the rear sight in the other direction.
It should go without saying, but adjustment or repair on a firearm should only be performed by people who have been trained to do it properly and safely. This tool should only be used on the slide and sight of a pistol that is unloaded and disassembled in accordance with its manufacturer's instructions. Also note: a number of aftermarket sights have lock screws which must be released before they can be adjusted. Trying to move one with this press when it is locked will result in damage to the press, the sight, and or the slide.

MangoT21's Beefed Up Replicator Extruder Bracket is quite nice.  On his Replicator 1, he found that he needed to move the filament guide holes backwards 0.1 inches; whereas, on my Replicator 1, I found that the original guide holes were correctly centered for my extruders. Marked as a work in progress until tested.

If you've ever had to work on a project that needed capturing high fidelity audio, you may have come across the ever so popular H4N audio recorder. For an upcoming project, I needed to use the handy device as a boom mic.   
Using a on-stage mic stand with the H4N makes a perfect combination for a boom-mic.

Because of the ridges between the layers of a 3d printed part, the threads get etched into the cavity of the adapter. The tolerances hold up nicely with a diameter of 14mm printed with 2 shells, 10% infill, 0.2 layer height and 90/150 speeds. The most common mic stand has a metal rod with a threaded tip that has a diameter of 13.5mm. To secure the connector and attachment pieces together, we'll need a metal screws with plastic knobs and a screw nut. This simple 2-piece design secures the H4N to the on-stage mic stand rather nicely. Notice the cavity is almost too big to hold the screw nut. This can easily be corrected by adjusting the sketch ~0.3mm smaller. The connector and attachment pieces have these tiny ridges on the surface where the two parts connect; causing friction when tightened and locked into position.ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ I got this idea from an camera lighting mount that has a similar swivel type mount. Notice how some of the ridges are scuffed up. This is from the ridges smashing into each other from the initial installation. The may wear down over time, but I don't plan on moving it that much. It's very convenient when audio/video devices use standard mounting holes, common among tripods and the H4N has one in the back of the device. The screw has a plastic knob and a standard tripod thread. The knob secures the attachment part to the H4N by fastening through the mounting hole of the attachment piece. It was actually scrapped from the very camera light which gave me the idea for the ridges in the adapter. Since the length of screw was too big, I used a cylinder to create spacer that would keep the pieces tight when fastened together. The two piece design allows for tilting the H4N in different positions. The knob is loosened and tightened to adjust the position. The screw nut keeps the connector and attachment parts secured when the knob is tightened. The screw nut itself is held inside a cavity on the outside of the adapter. More information http://www.adafruit.com/blog/?p=114145

To get my "Iron 3d 9x9x12 kit" to be better / work for me. Large Idler mount:
The mount is wider,where you can put in a whole pulley. If you have parts drilled a bit off / your belt gets jammed against the side of your bearing mount, this may be part of a solution for you. I plan on redrilling the stepper motor mount some, and changing the mount on the bottom of the printer bed at some point. Currently I made a pulley out of PTFE on my dremel and a jewelry graver... not perfect but I think it solved the issues I was having. FYI, There may be a rather ugly mesh line near two of the holes.. everything printed in a functional capacity though. Spool holder:
mount was originally made to hold a BBQ skewer, but thats not quite long enough... using a z threaded rod at the moment. Bolts into the top, where the z Rod retainer brace is. It could use a redesign sometime, the grove needs to be deeper so you can move the printer around with everything securely in place, but it does the job for now.

use 2mm Grid on pulley mount, and course supports

I bought a couple of 1Kg spools of filament, however they come from a large spool that does not fit on my Ormerod's holder. I made this simple little design that fits inside the spool, has a low friction base and fits over a CD Spindle.
I anchored the CD spindle to the desk, and placed the spool of filament on the guide. I have had no further problems with feeding the printer, and the shape of the guide and the arms provide a little springiness which causes the spool to remain centered and turning. NOTE: Prints with no support required. Just ensure that the 1st couple of layers stick properly to the bed because they have very little surface area (low friction).

simple robot mascot

I was inspired by this CNC pendant, but I wanted to make one that I could hack on my own, add buttons, change functionality, and that I could guarantee would work well with my Shopbot. The way this works is you plug it into your Shopbot controller computer, and enter "Keyboard Control Mode" in the control software. The red/green/blue buttons on the pendant change you into "X/Y/Z" axis mode. Then the jog wheel moves the machine. The jog wheel button puts you into "detail" mode, where each movement steps the machine by a much more precise amount. Naturally, you could expand this, for example add a button for "jog" mode to move the machine faster, or add buttons to zero the X/Y/Z axes. Here's a parts + tools list:
  • 3D Printer (I use a Makerbot 5th Gen) + filament
  • Arduino Micro - I used the "headerless" version and then soldered on some 0.1" female headers so I could add/remove wires willy-nilly.
  • Perma-proto 1/2-sized PCB
  • Colorful round tactile buttons
  • Rotary encoder
  • 8mm through-hole Neopixel
  • Hookup wire + soldering iron + solder etc. if you don't already have that stuff

3D Print the parts, no supports should be needed, but I had better success with rafts on a Makerbot 5th gen. Solder / assemble the electronics as indicated from the diagrams. You can get everything there from http://adafruit.com . Download the "shopbot_pendant_micro.ino" file to your Arduino Micro. Put it together. It's pretty straightforward to assemble, though you might have to file the box top a bit to get it to stick in the lid.

title: Henry VIII's Crown
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
For non-commercial use only.
A re-creation of Henry VIII'?s Crown - originally worn by the Tudor King at Hampton Court Palace. As a potent symbol of power and religious authority, the original was destroyed at the Tower of London in 1649 by Oliver Cromwell, following the abolition of the monarchy. Made of silver gilt and comprising 344 rubies, sapphires, emeralds, diamonds and pearls and five religious sculptures, it was painstakingly recreated in 2012 by the then Crown Jeweler, Harry Collins, following extensive research by Historic Royal Palaces'? curators into original inventories and contemporary paintings.
This reconstruction has been scanned using structured light 3D scanning and cross polarised photogrammetry to produce this model.
To see a video of this model being printed using Selective Laser Sintering (SLS) and Stereolithography (SLA) printing techniques visit: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NcUJYM-sv2E

title: Fabiano Porcini, Pigman Rocker
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
NAME: Fabiano Porcini
ORIGIN: Pig-Earth
OCCUPATION: Rock Star Formerly the head of the trans-universally acclaimed hair-metal band, Iron Thunder, and four-time winner of Battle Axes (a Teledrome production) Fabiano now makes a paltry living on an ill-received solo act. Once considered the foremost Power-Grunter in the known universes, Fabianoâ€™s poor leadership skills failed to keep his band together. Though he spends most of his days in the Nexus Undercity in between casino gigs, Fabiano has recently received noteworthy praise for his back-up grunting on Hott Trappâ€™s latest album, Kold Swett. Model designed in TinkerCAD and Sculptris https://tinkercad.com/things/dd9uN1NuUE7-fabiano-porcini-pigman-rocker-30characterschallenge This is my first entry for the 30 Characters Challenge. Each day in November I'll be designing and posting a new model (though the prints may come a tad later, depending on how on-the-ball I am). Each character is randomly generated using the Continuum Narrative Engine (a storytelling game system currently in the works here at the Ill Gotten Games headquarters). http://www.30characters.com/2012/11/01/11012012-fabiano-porcini-pigman-rocker-3/

So this guy is a bit of a WIP. The pole in the print is just to keep his highest feature from getting deformed (I'm printing him in PLA and still learning the ropes). He was printed with a 10% infill at a .10 layer height, extruder temp at 230. After he was assembled, he was painted with water-based acrylics. Not my best work, but I think the details will come out better when I can print him at a lower temperature. Also, in future assemblies, I'm planning on sealing his seam line with modeling epoxy.

description.text:
This is an assembly jig to build chassis for RC vehicles. It is used to square the whole chassis build. In the photos you can see how the wheelbase is controlled with the placement of the axles and the parts used to do so. I will be adding to this as I build more additions to the jig. Base Mounts:
Are used to mount other pieces and parts to the Jigs Base. Wheelbase/Axle Mounts:
Are used to hold the axles at a specific distance form each other for creating the Wheelbase for the chassis to be built. As well as the hold the axles ridged for control arm mounts.

Assembly Jig Base:
It is a piece of plate Aluminum 12\" wide x 24\" long x 1/4\" thick with 8-32 holes at 1\" increments.
Base Mounts:
Are 1/8\" x 3/4\" Aluminum angle cut to 1/2\" lengths and drilled with a #29 drill bit(.136\") centered on one leg of the angle. And a slot is cut on the other leg using a 3/16\" end mill centered in the leg starting 5/16" from the outer corner of the angle.
Wheelbase/Axle Mounts:
Are 1/8\" x 2\" x 2-1/2\" flat Aluminum with a slot cut using a 3/16\" end mill 1-1/2\" long centered in the length and measured down from the top edge 1/2\" There are also two holes drilled in the bottom corners to hold the \"Base Mounts\". The slot is marked from the center of the slot to each end on 1/8" intervals. To make placing the axle exactly where the designer prefers.

Make sure filament is straight in extruder for better grip. -- Permet de s'assurer que le fil rentre bien droit dans la partie froide de l'extrudeur.
Permet un meilleur grip.

• Print ;)
  • fix it with 2 wood screw
  • Enjoy

The NEX-7 is a great camera, but it does have some shortcomings. One of them is that you have to hold down the trigger when doing bracketing shots. This is a problem when you are doing it at night with long exposure times, because it will introduce camera shake and make your pictures blurry. You also cannot use the IR remote to trigger the bracketing shots. Maybe Sony will fix this in a later firmware release, but for now this Thing will provide a solution.

You will need to buy a cable release and one of those velcro adapters to go with it. I bought mine from Amazon (http://goo.gl/fmeA6O) but I am sure you can get them from a lot of places. You will have to remove the metal adapter from the velcro strap. It must be one that you can screw apart. The hole in the Thing is for a 1cm diameter. Yours may be different, in which case you need to change the OpenSCAD file to your measurements.
The ring fits very snug around the base of the lens flange. It is best to remove the lens when attaching the adapter to the camera.

I got sick of using my Leatherman's pliers to hold my 1/4-20 Tap Drill, therefore I quickly designed a nice, ergonomically friendly chuck for 5mm square-ended tap drills.  Simply take your 5mm square-ended tap drill, insert it into either side of the chuck and tap that piece...of plastic.

Download and print this 5mm x 5mm tap drill chuck to make tapping whatever parts easy (useful for projects such as the 3D printed tripod: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33357) I added stress concentration relief points so it should last you some time unless you're tapping stainless steel or some other harder metals. When I get around to learning OpensCAD, I'll make parametric files so you could easily scale this down to get a tap drill holder for smaller tap drills. Enjoy!

description.text: After struggling using the cardboard sided spools for a while, it has become apparent that the filament is being dragged towards the inside of the spool, causing jamming. I found online someone who had used acrylic discs to stop the cardboard from flexing. Removing the cardboard sides of the spools, and replacing them with acryllic discs, has proved to be a much more reliable delivery system. The acrylic discs cost £3 each to be laser cut from the drawings included. To assemble this also requires an M10 x 50mm countersunk bolt and nylock nut, and 2 x m4 x 50mm countersunk bolts with nylock nuts. You remove one side of the cardboard spool, fit the acrylic disk with printed bobbin through the centre of the spool, then remove the other side of the cardboard spool, and bolt on the secont piece of acrylic. It is not as complicated as it sounds, and once assembled makes a very sturdy piece. It is definately worth the effort, IMHO!

Icehouse is a board gaming system (like a deck of cards) with a dedicated community of fans. There are 3 types of pyramids: small, medium, and large. a set of 3 pyramids is called a "nest", and a set of 5 nests is called a "stash". Icehouse pyramids can be used to play any of the 300+ games found at http://www.icehousegames.org. Many games can be played with only one stash, but with 5 stashes (and a few odds and ends like playing cards and dice) you can play almost every game on the site. The coolest part about Icehouse is the community that has been built around inventing and sharing games. Sadly it seems to be stagnating a bit lately, so maybe the thingiverse community can help revitalize things? I designed these in sketchup using the official specifications found here: http://www.wunderland.com/icehouse/MakingIcehouse.html

I originally meant to print these in batches of 6 pyramids (2 nests per print), but have found that this results in ugly and misshapen pyramids. While the results are usable, I'd recommend printing them out one pyramid at a time to make sure you have good looking nest that fits together well.
I have included an stl file for printing either one or two stashes in one print if you're in a hurry though. I'd be interested to hear if anyone prints a good looking set, since I might just have skeinforge set up wrong.

I needed an air flow duct/case around the RAMPS board inside my MendelMax, but none of the existing things seemed to fit. Because there are so many of these cases, it seemed an interesting thought to make a modular version, so it becomes possible to make many kinds of ducts/cases with a single set of components. Attached STL's are for a 60mm fan and RAMPS 1.4 board and my setup. Note that I use a floorboard inside my MendelMax (see thing 28669), so the modules are designed to be screwed to a flat surface, rather than somehow connected to each other.

description.text:
These are updated to fit better, Oct 2, 2014.
There is an updated Sabertooth 2x12 case made just for the tank with a receiver case in the Tank, Electronics cases in my things.
Wanted to share this cover and lid for Sabertooth 2X12 robotic dual motor speed controller. Mounted a Sabertooth 2x12 on the back top of my tank project, needed to be protected, specially if it lands on its top. Here is a case designed to cover the controller with a lid. Also some blocks to screw to rails if needed. Holes in ends to put wires through. Can supply a case without holes so you can drill your own if needed.
Tank project, am designing and building an RC tank with 3D printed suspension and track. Has dual 540 motors, Kyosho high speed worm gear sets with bearings in 3D printed gears cases, Sabertooth 2x12 dual motor controller, swing arm front track tensioner design. Tank is 17.25" long x 10" wide, has 2.375" of ground clearance, long travel suspension.
There are two YouTube videos of the tank. One with Dual Mabuchi RS540 motors and one with Dual Brushless Traxxas Velineon 3500/VXL-3S running on dual 3S lipo batteries. Tank hits 11mph with Velineon motors.
Have shared a lot of the parts for track and suspension in my things.
Youtube video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dRz3TS2hO10

comments.text: There are no dumb questions, only a lack of understanding or explanation. Yes they are O-rings. They really helped the track run smoother and quieter. Give a little cushion on the idler wheels (rollers). The weight of the tank is on the O-rings in between the roller idler wheels and the top of the track. The side to side of the track is held by the step up on the roller in the center. It fits in the grove in the middle of track the drive sprocket goes in.

description.text: Let the dominoes fall! Everyone loves domino tumbles, and setting them up is super easy and fast with these pre-racked tracks. Even little kids can do it - turn a piece over to swing the dominoes into place, and line them up for a chain reaction. Curves and forks let your road run everywhere!

Dynamite Dominoes are simple to build and assemble: 1. Use the accompanying files to print the tracks you want. 2. Print five dominoes per track (three for forks). (Using a second color looks great!) 3. Carefully pop the dominoes into their track slots using a small screwdriver. 4. Youâ€™re ready to go! Accompanying .stl files provide the basics. A .zip file includes plates with other awesome domino-track combinations, along with SketchUp sources to let you customize and put together the perfect kit! Printing Tips - I get excellent results printing the tracks at 10% fill and the dominoes at 25% fill (to give them some mass), with one extra shell. However, I recommend doing a small test print to make sure the pieces fit correctly before moving on to bigger plates.

description.text: An OpenSCAD model of one of the underwater vehicles from the Octonauts/Meomi cartoons.

Requires the MCAD library. Change the parameters to make various kinds of Gup-like shapes. The optional parameter tow_line changes the rear of the gup to have a tow line looking thing, it's not perfect, but similar to what the Gup-C would have. The default parameters are suitable for printing, but the model is a bit fragile in that the parameter space that creates feasible models is small. front_radius: controls the front globe where the cockpit sits.
back_radius: controls the back globe where the propeller shaft attaches.
port_hole_radius: sizes the port holes along the side.
various shaft parameters: adjust if you already have a propeller, or for the included three-arm parametric propeller. The body prints OK on a MakerBot Replicator but, the back is a bit too steep and the surface rips up some. Some of the "doodads" like the porthole outer rings and the "lamp" have trouble occasionally.

Semi-useful for shredding or making ribbons out of not-too-hard and not-too-soft foods. (Too soft, and it gets destroyed by cranking action, too hard and it won't cut - this is plastic, not metal). Attach knob using M3 screw and two nuts. Glue either "xholder" or "spiked holder" (only for harder stuff) onto end of crank after inserting thru pusher. Notch in disc lines up inside retainer ring. Screw ring onto body, insert pusher into body, apply pressure, and crank away. Tested with Japanese cucumber - made some nice curly strings out of it... see photo. More of an exercise than a real useful tool. But give it a shot. Warning! Use at your own risk!
  • Possibility of plastic coming loose into food unknown.
  • Food contamination risk unknown.
  • Injury risk unknown

I use ABS a lot. And i have the great replicator hood cover from drandolph designs.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23386
Making big things with ABS tends to leave some bad fumes on the air.
I noticed that drandolph designs had some holes and cuts for some exhausting system. So i decided to make one.

You need a 40mm fan for this Exhaust System I printed both parts at:
10% Infill
0.27 Layer Height
2 Shells Once printed, cut the aid rib from the Exhaust Block. If you can use a Tap on the holes for the fan with 3mm. Mount the fan on the Exhaust Block and the two on the back of the hood with four M3 screws. Insert the filter in the Exhaust Cover and assemble. (For the filter i use carbon active sponge) May also interest you the following things:
Exhaust System 80mm for Replicator
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33642 Electronics Box for Exhaust System 80mm Replicator
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33648

description.text: Another LED candle holder, but with OpenSCAD files instead of *.123d files. I made the top of the candle a bit more distorted than the original to give it a 'molten' look. The second holder (holder2.scad) was an experiment with low current LEDs that didn't work out. The third holder (holder3.scad) uses my own flickering LED implementation with a PIC12F508 (https://github.com/holgero/PICFlickerLEDs).

For the original thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33003 use the files candle. and holder.. For my own flickering LEDs implementation use the holder3. files instead of holder.. It goes upside down into the candle and the LED sticks through the holes in the disk, see the attached images. The flickering LEDs PIC assembler sources are available on github: https://github.com/holgero/PICFlickerLEDs. The openscad file uses the switch component from the 3D-PCB library http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21975 . The thing contains also a battery clip (like the two battery holder from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:38216 . To make your own you need one printout of candle.scad, holder3.scad and clip2.scad (from the Parametric Battery Clip Thing). Other stuff is: 1 LED (yellow), 1 resistor 68 Ohms, 1 PIC 18F508 (and the means to flash it with a hex file) and some wire. Assemble the battery clip, thread the wires so that the batteries are connected in series. Assemble the switch (see http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-Printed-Circuit-Boards-for-solder-free-printab/ ). Flash a PIC 12F580 with the hex file (either compile it from the sources on github or use the PICFlickerLEDs.hex file from here) and connect it as seen on the image. The yellow LED is connected with its longer leg (+) to the peg in the middle of the picture (Vdd) and on the other end with the 68 Ohms resistor. Connect the other end of the resistor with one of the pins 2,3,5,6,7 of the PIC (doesn't matter which, they all output some flickering). Connect pin 1 with the peg in the middle (Vdd) and pin 8 with GND (-) from the battery pack. Note that the PIC in the image is shown from below, so the PIN 1 is on the top right (the one connected to the middle peg).

description.text:
This enclosure has space for the fan, Arduino UNO and GShield plus a small board to screw in the wires for LImit Switches. Be careful to note the hole positions on your limit switch board or it will be crooked like mine :=} I decided not to change it since it's still functional. The corner anchors were 3D printed, however you may want to use Ø3mm brass standoffs instead because they have threads and would be better if you needed to open it often. The only thing I don't like is you can't get at the reset buttons on the cards. Perhaps someone will improve on my design. :=}
It's mounted to the Shapeoko Plate via the acrylic 1/4" bracket that I threaded for Ø5mm screws. All sides and bracket were assembled using Weld-On. Make sure you dry fit first before applying Weld-On.
http://www.amazon.com/Weld-On-Acrylic-Adhesive-Applicator-Bottle/dp/B0096TWKCW/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1400526862&sr=8-1&keywords=weld+on+4. UPDATE
http://youtu.be/6VvwGszE8Xo This video shows that the stock version of Shapeoko 2 does TECHNICALLY function as advertised. However, it's very unreliable and can be downright dangerous. I had to go through 2 of those 1/4" thick sheets to get the small bracket above to cut properly. It's unreliable behavior wastes time and money on materials. That's what Inventables counts on, money from people having to buy materials. I have since discontinued using the machine until I obtain a TinyG stepper motor controller. The GRBLShield is poorly designed and allows way too much electrical noise to be generated which has caused my Shapeoko 2 to plunge unexpectedly into the waste board and actually breaking my fine engraving bits. This has happened twice when I invoked the Homing Command. The hard limits option doesn't work because of all the electrical interference so there's no protection. If you have to have a Shapeoko, buy the mechanical kit, NEMA 23 motors and TinyG. The full kit has faulty electronics and small motors. Who needs a glorified "Spyrograph" ?

description.text: The is Chaucer, a vertical 3d printer derived from Dave Kennell's pocket printer at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19891# Like the Pocket Printer, the Chaucer frame is constructed with 20x20 and 2x60 Misumi extrusions. It is modeled after a vertical milling machine. A light and fast print bed moves on the X-Y axis via stepper motor timing belt drive trains. The print head, or extruder is heavier, and moves on the Z-axis via a lead screw drive train. A few sample parts have been uploaded to this Thingiverse site. The "real" design files can be found on GitHub at https://github.com/ronsheely/Chaucer http://RonSheely.com https://IronwoodLabs.com http://dots.IronwoodLabs.com

I completed my first successful print on Chaucer, a vertical 3d printer. The printer and associated project is called Chaucer, named after Geoffrey Chaucer, the ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ Father of English Literature. Chaucer the printer is modeled after a vertical milling machine, making it a very useful tool to experiment with high speed printing and prototype print heads. Chaucer is a derived from an earlier printer designed by David Kennell, posted on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19891. When I decided to design and build a printer that would help me develop a deep understanding of the 3d print pipeline, and to provide a test platform for high speed printing with multiple experimental print heads, I knew I needed to model it after a vertical milling machine. David's open source project, which he dubbed the Pocket Printer, gave me a great place to start. David's generous help was instrumental to my success. The maximum print volume is: xyz = 160, 180, 110 mm.
The current print volume is set in firmware to xyz = 160, 140, 110 mm because I misplaced the heated print bed. I will fix that. I will submit detailed instructions and files as time permits. If you need something, please let me know. Here is a video of my first successful print. It's not perfect, but easily fixed. See http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4djXJ5xvO8o I uploaded the trapezoid foot files in both OpenSCAD and STL format. The scad file makes use of ruler model found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30769 The foot is a modified version of the rear feet of the Pocket Printer.

An OpenSCAD model of a wheel, probably best suited for a toy truck, etc.
Model can be rendered for DualStrusion, too.

Requires the MCAD library. Also, the default OpenSCAD tree element limit prevents the OpenCSG library from rendering this in the quick view. It renders fine if you change that, e.g., to 8000. (Edit/Preferences/Advanced)
Adjust the OpenSCAD parameters to vary the wheel radius and width, number of vents, shaft diameter, and tread depth.
The default values create a wheel similar to those on a Tonka truck one of my kids have.
The top-level component has a single parameter to select between three models: 0=the whole wheel, -1=tread only, +1=hub only. This is useful for exporting the two pieces for dualstrusion.
update: slight modification to the hub- dualstrusion was continuing to be problematic, so I've added some ribs at the base to firm up the hub during the first 5mm of layers.

A build plate of various optical components:
(1) an XY-stage
(2) a linear rail for translation
(3) some caps/holders
(4) mounts for rails, stages, etc.
(5) base mounting plates The ultimate goal for these components is to enable a printable compound microscope.

Most parts have 4-40 cap bolt holes, which self-thread, for either positioning (for the XY-stage) or as set screws (for the rail and mounts) The linear rail can be stacked end-on with two other rails by joining them (with some 4-40 bolts) on a common base plate. The base plate does have trouble printing at low infill. The XY-stage uses four thin, S-springs at the corners which will bind up at the extremes of the translation... you can get about +/-5mm with the current design, but some diagonal positions require "convincing". The cuvette and cap included in this build plate are from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33638

title: Cardboard Brick to make a Roman Arch

description.text:
This is the net for a brick you can fold out of 3mm cardboard. It is sized to make the largest possible brick I could on my 18X24 Epilog Laser bed. If you print nine of these, you can make a roman arch. They were used in 6th Grade history to introduce Roman history. Tape is not needed to hold this together (it was used by students in their "dig" to show they'd tampered with the site). Prompt 1: A Simulated Dig.
We printed ~100 and left them around as an archeological dig with some large 3D printed artifacts:
Hadrian's Bust http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:248216
Roman Torso http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:26536
A relief http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:239387
Random Egyptian Artefact http://www.thingiverse.com/make:78124
Bones (for good measure) http://www.thingiverse.com/make:52940
The students then had to identify what the original structure was and justify their conclusions based on research. Prompt 2: Building with Arches.
Students were first paired in teams of two and told to build the arch together. Once they figured out how to do so, they could work with other teams and build objects that used multiple arches. In the pictures you can see them trying to build an aqueduct, dome, etc.

author: pupil

description.text:
This is a little mobile phone stand, designed to fold into a compact package (about 2" x 2" x 1/4").
Works with just about any mobile phone and case, and if it doesn't, feel free to alter the OpenSCAD file!

Update: The print plate now has the two parts side by side - it was very difficult to separate the interleaved print. The object has been modified with more, thinner, arms and a small "bushing" to provide friction in the hinge.
Alternatively you can print the long arms and short arms separately, using the appropriate STL files.
Line up the pieces so the screw holes line, and thread an M3 50mm bolt through. Put an M3 nut on the other end and tighten it to pull the nut into the recess. You're done!
The stand has two positions - open the shorter arms 90 degrees, and it works well for phones in landscape orientation. Keep moving the short arms around to 270 degrees, and you can rest the phone on them, best for portrait orientation.
You can adjust the tolerances for your machine in the OpenSCAD file, look for the variable 'spacing'. You may need to adjust the arm thickness too.

There's a couple more of these on here, but I thought I'd throw one in that looks like the standard one you can pick up online for cheap these days.  Would look cool printed in Laywoo, I bet.  
NOTE:  print handle with solid or near-solid infill, or breakage will likely occur. 
Use at own risk...  I have no clue about the food safety characteristics of printed plastics. yadda yadda...  
If you need a good recipe and a video on how to use this.  Google it... there are scads.
Probably can print the board with lighter infill. Only crucial parts are around threads. So maybe use an extra perimeter and less infill?   Print handle with solid or near solid.

comments.text: I printed it out and used it this weekend. Makes beautiful gnocchi.  I was amazed at how easily the handle screwed in, however, the infill on the handle has to be higher, so a separate print is needed . It snapped off while I was cleaning it.  The board also lifted from the raft during printing, so the grooves are not perfect from end to end.  That could have been an error on my end. Since you really only need a small area, it was not an issue.

comments.text:
Now a scanner which can do that would actually be useful to me. I could use it to make stuff...
I'd like your opinion on something. I think the lack of a good, inexpensive scanner is all that stands in the way of 3D printers becoming as commonplace as microwave ovens. A quick google search shows an approximate price for one of the scanners ... Artec MH... at around $13,500... You can buy 10 printers for that kind of money so not a lot of recreational users will go for it..
How many years would you estimate it will be before a similar quality scanner hits the marketplace for at or below the price of the average hobby printer? Is it impossible to say because there are technical requirements and / or limitations which nothing but new invention can overcome?
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text:
In my opinion it is about the same as a 3D printer, if yo think about it the technique of FDM/FFF/MEM is relatively simple but software is the key. Artec has great scanners that use structured white and now blue light. And they have great software that is still improving, they provide regular updates that really improve the end result. For example with the newest version 9.2 of Artec Studio I can scan things I could not 1.5 years ago (and the results were good then). So they could have a good head start but will have to remain innovative.
I do think prices will dramatically drop within a few years, there are already a few that have potential to sell a lot of machines. But I do think the scanner has to have a light source, much better results than IR or photo's like 123DCatch or Sense (Sense has great software too, great for 3D printing!).
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text:
Thanks. From what little I know about it, the structured light methods do seem to be the most promising..
One of my concerns is 3D printing being less valuable or useful than other purposes, like facial recognition... medical treatment, etc, so the hobbiest printing world is not targeted by developers.
I don't need a zillion data points, or to capture movement, to help design or duplicate things. A reasonably accurate (no better than the printer can print) shape....outlines and curved surfaces... would suffice in virtually all cases.
comments.author: 3DWP

comments.text: Then maybe you should check the 3D Systems Sense (Handscanner), doesn't have structured light but scans objects greater than 20 cm (8 inches) relatively well. A very promising laser table scanner is the Matter and Form 3D scanner (previously Matterform Photon). Not out yet but soon to be delivered to Indiegogo backers, one of which is ME :-)

These tags are designed to be used on cylinders to mark full and empty. I printed the "empty" in red and the "full" in green. Then with a little bit of acetone they were joined back to back. I tied a piece of paracord through the holes and put it over the valve. When the tanks come in they are all marked full and when we switch out an empty they get flipped to the red empty side. Works for welding cylinders, home oxygen, bbq propane tanks, ect. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/gHHtSRLCB32

Best to print in two separate colors ie red= empty green = full but not necessary.  Print them and then use a little acetone or abs glue to join the pieces back to back.  Make a hanging loop with paracord or string so it can hang off the tank valve.

description.text:
This is a rack and pinion system designed to be used with Lego Tetrix parts.   
The Herringbone design captures the rack and provides support with out the need for rails.  
The pictures only show the right handed gear. I flipped the gear on the motor so that it would work. In the future I will use the right handed gear.

This is still a work in progress.
The openscad file contains as modules for the gears racks and also some other useful tetrix parts. When printed out of ABS on a Makerbot2x the shrink caused the holes on the end of the rack to be tight. You may need to scale if printing in ABS to account for the shrink. I have only printed one rack and have not verified if they will but end to end properly.

author: zMath

description.text:
Maintain the lowest amount of friction possible on your filament feeding system.... and this will help!  
The UM2 bowden-style extruder feeds from the bottom but didn't have a filament guide aligned vertically below the extruder's opening. This caused stress and friction while feeding.  
I searched around and found Wired1's design and liked it the best and decided to use it as my starting point.  I used a small 3M command strip to affix the mount to the back of the Ultimaker, making for easy removal.

My filament hangs above and behind the printers, so I printed multiple copies of this pulley to route the filament. Print:
1x Mount
1x Block
2x Wheel You will also need:
1x 693 bearing
1x M3x18 (or 20) screw
1x M3x16 screw
2x M3 nuts
1x small 3M Command Strip Fit 693 bearing into center of one Wheel piece. Sandwich the other wheel piece to complete the wheel. Fit the Wheel into the Block and align with holes. Use the 18-or-20mm M3 screw to lock the wheel in place. Do not over tighten. Complete the pulley by using the 16mm M3 screw to connect the Block to the Mount. Tip: Use Plasti-Dip on the outer portion of the tri-sided legs of the wheel that hold the bearing in place (the portion that will touch the filament once the wheel is assembled)... this will create a grip so that wheel turns with any/all filament movement.... it really helps to see issues quickly.

comments.text:
Let me know if I don't explain it well:
There are basically 3 parts: the switch knob, the 'pulleys', and the two pull handles.
The switch knob is where you start; tie / thread it so that there is one end of fishing line coming out of each hole near the tip (one of these will be the on thread / the other is off)
The off thread first goes through a pulley below it (like in the default picture) and then simply goes up to the one above the switch, where it will join the on thread (from here on out they will be side by side through the rest of the pulleys) and use as many pulleys as you need, then finally tie each end to its designated pull handle.
The pulleys are made so that they can be screwed into place first and then threaded, and then capped to hide the screw.
comments.author: FireflyII

title: Printrbot 2.1 Carriage Conversion IMPROVED + Side Channel Blower Rev. C

description.text: Geday guys, I have updated this yet again and it now fits the Printrbot aluminium extruder (or the plastic version http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:281015). It needs an adjustment for the holes for mounting the blower, but I've now just stuck the blower on with double sided tape. I didn't complete it because I've now moved to the new Printrbot carriage design. You'll need to print this in ABS, then acetone glue on the little air dam on the side. It's designed to take a 50mm 12v blower on the side. The reason I opted for this is because the efficiency is better and the design is dramatically cleaner. It also made some room to fit an autolevel probe. Also the blower is a lot quieter than an axial fan. Anyway, more than anything I've put this up to give some ideas to modders, and having a mostly complete design to work from saves you a lot of time in the drawing seat. I've probably done 1000 hours printing on this carriage and the performance has been brilliant. Edit 1 - Forgot to include autolevel probe

comments.text: I'm thinking you could also try modifying the part slightly by making that surface a shade thicker, that might reduce the warp. From memory, I did the print at 0.3 layer height on fast, as I knew it was going to warp and keeping heat of the part was important. I was planning to do another revision of this but changed to the new style carriage in the end.
comments.author: ob1bsmokin

comments.text: I printed it on an UP! Mini using UP! ABS. I did have some warping but straightened it with a hair dryer. It's just one of those parts that warps a bit doe to the shape of it. I printed it with the extruder mating side down, so upside down basically. That minimised support. That's the side that warped slightly, but at the end of the day a slight warp doesn't affect the part a lot.
comments.author: ob1bsmokin

comments.text: Heaps better. I've been on it just over a week and have never had to touch the bed level since. Printrbot specifically have some firmware that supports this. Like I said though, if you don't want to use the autolevel routine and stuff, you can just use it as a super accurate Z sensor. You can get these sensors from the Printrbot store or from your favourite auction site. You do need a metal bed for it to work properly. That said, you could also do it with a sheet of something under the sensor to calibrate it and work out the offset, but that's a bit tricky. Ultimately, I'd recommend metal bed for any machine just because it's dead flat.
comments.author: VintageTimeAustralia

description.text:
A tool holder with slots for SD cards, hex wrenches (aka allen keys), screwdrivers, pliers, side-cutters, scissors, pens, etc.
Although I keep post-it notes, a scalpel and digital verniers in it too, I wouldn't recommend doing so as their slots are not designed well and could do with improvements.
Derived from Replicator thing:23520 by MangoT21, except this one if free-standing.  SketchUp design also uploaded.

NOTE! This is a LARGE print - the raft actually went over the edge of my build platform for this one.  
Note that RepG took a very long time to slice this (over one hour), perhaps because I used a higher fill than I normally would.  
The print itself was a LONG time on the Replicator (12-18 hrs) on the default RepG and 5.5 Firmware.  I'd definitely encourage use of the Sailfish firmware instead, given the long dimensions involved you should see a massive improvement in print time.

description.text:
Tested and working - open source, quick, simple, standard (2" PVC connector available at any hardware store).  Used when your filament comes on a crappy cardboard spool.  Print 2 sides and use PVC glue to glue sides onto a standard 2" PVC pipe connector.  180mm in diameter and takes a full 1kg of filament, rolls easily on 3/4" PVC pipe.  Needs an 8x8 bed.  If you scale it down, it won't fit the 2" PVC connector.  
I use a battery powered drill and a bolt glued into a 3/4" PVC pipe, taped up, to respool from a cardboard spool.  Works well and I no longer get jams from the cardboard sides spreading and the filament falling into the crack.

comments.author: bobnojio

comments.text: This was designed for USA schedule 40 pipe CONNECTORS, not pipe.  Your description sounds like you're using the pipe.  I used connectors because they are a consistent size with square ends and they're about the right length.  1kg of filament fits on the spool.  I didn't use pipe due to the difficulty of getting square ends with hand tools.  I've since found out UK pipe is sized differently so this should be considered a USA design.

My Droid RAZR Maxx has a speaker on the back where the audio for video playback and music comes through.  This is fine when I've placed the phone screen-down, but it would be nice to have an elegant way to prop it up so I can watch a movie, show, or just have the screen face me while it's sitting out.
Basically, this is a little squished sphere with a Droid cutout and a circular tunnel cutout so that the audio can (hopefully) travel from the back of the phone to the listener in front.  It would also really help as a stand for speaker-phone mode.
I'll try printing it tomorrow and let you know how it goes.  :)
The OpenSCAD file is poorly documented and not very parametric.  Nevertheless, I've included it if you're a glutton for such punishment.  :)
Update - I made some minor changes to the model, including allowing clearance for a USB cable and reducing the overall size of the stand.

title: Adjustable Z Endstop for MakerFarm Prusa i3v

description.text:
Note: there are two versions of the switch bracket. Choose the longer one if you have the newer endstop switches with wheels on the arms. Note: this part fits the 8" i3v. The 10" printer has longer X extrusions that block the screw unless you trim the excess length. As requested, here is my adjustable Z endstop for the MakerFarm Prusa i3v. If you've got an i3v, you've probably been waiting for this.
This thing includes a new switch bracket to relocate the Z limit switch on the right side of the right-hand Z extrusion and an adjustment screw plate that mounts to the bottom of the lower X extrusion.
See the instructions for recommended mounting hardware.
Thanks to DogByte for the suggestion. If there are other parts you want for the i3v, just leave a comment below.
If you're looking for better X and Y endstops, too, you may wish to consider this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:321810
UPDATE: I now also have a micrometer-adjustable Z endstop available: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:356819

The switch bracket mounts to the right-hand side of the right Z extrusion. The screw bracket mounts to the underside of the bottom X-axis extrusion with an M5 bolt and T-nut. My kit had extras, so I didn't have to buy any hardware.
For the adjusting screw, I recommend an M3x20. You can use an M3x16 left over from the i3v kit, but you won't have as much adjustment range. Just slide the switch bracket up and down to make a rough adjustment and then use the screw to dial it in.
I tapped the adjustment screw hole with an M3 tap, but found that I wanted the screw a little tighter. You may wish to just force the screw in so it makes its own threads and sticks in place more securely.
To mount the switch, use M2.5x12mm screws. You can tap the holes, but I just forced them in so they made their own threads. Make sure the switch still operates freely after mounting. The switches that come with the MakerFarm kit can bind if you tighten the screws too much.
You can slide the screw plate on the X extrusion to line the adjustment screw up with the switch lever and then lock it down. I installed my X extrusions so they're contacting the stops on the left side, so it lined up nicely. If you have trouble lining it up, let me know and I can make adjustments to the parts. Note: there are two versions of the switch bracket. Choose the longer one if you have the newer endstop switches with wheels on the arms.

title: Pandemic board game parts + cards holders

description.text:
Needed a way to keep the cubes accessible and organized. This uses the same design as my quadcopter blade box except with curves to allow you to remove the cubes.  
The 2 decks with the game need a discard pile each so I needed 4 deck holders that could fit into the space of 2.   
Included are the SolidWorks files for all the parts except for the partbox-single.STL. This is because I just cannot get SolidWorks to agree with me on making the curve. The box I used for that was one of the early prototypes so I didn't have the original SolidWorks file.

You probably want to print with an extrusion width of 0.505 so that the inner walls are solid instead of having a slight gap.   
Also I find it best to print all this with a 3mm brim and just clean up with an xacto knife. The lid might need a bit of filing. You want it snug but not tight and not too loose.

description.text: A 'crusty' version of the micro-gear heart, allowing for different colors for the outside crust and inner body with dualstrusion. Pick your favorite colors!

This is a derivative of the amazing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24675 by CrazyJaw. I modified the OpenSCAD script to generate an outer crust. This produces two plates: One for the body and one for the crust, allowing to print them in different colors with dualstrusion (using the "merge .stl" feature of ReplicatorG - Ctrl+D). I also made a few minor improvements, such as creating a plate with all pieces properly positioned on the platform and a slightly improved packing. If you want to build from the OpenSCAD, have a look at the command lines in 'build.bat' to see how to select the body or crust plates (this is controlled through a boolean constant 'docrust' which has to be set from the command line). I printed mine on a Replicator 1 (Sailfish), 0.2mm layers, 20% infill, 80 mm/s feed rate and 160 mm/s travel. For mounting instruction please refer to the original. The pins are the same as in Thing 24675, I simply provide them here for ease of downloading. Enjoy!

title: SD card/adapter holder for RepRapPro Huxley

description.text:
If you keep "misplacing" your MicroSD card adapters, and wish you had a dedicated spot on your printer to keep one, then this thing is for you!   
It clips on to any vertical NEMA 14 stepper motor and gives you a convenient spot to store your favorite MicroSD card adapter for hassle-free uploads to your printer.
Simply print, clip on to any vertical stepper motor, and insert your favorite MicroSD adapter.

description.text:
Update: I was finally able to install this on my printer.  It looks like everything lines up and works correctly.  I've uploaded new .scad and .stl files however, there isn't anything significantly different in them.  The changes were all attribution in the code.  Enjoy!  
This is based on Zennmaster's i3 mounting bracket with mods to support the i3v.  
Tested with my MakerFarm Prusa i3v 8".  Everything seems to line up and work correctly.  
This features a slot to fit the servo cord through as well as cut-out to hold m2.5 nuts if you wish to screw in your servo motor.  These can both be disabled in the .scad file if desired.

To modify the features make changes to the .scad file and generate the slt using OpenSCAD. You will also need the Z-probe holder by Zennmaster, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:167430, to complete the auto-bed leveling set.

description.text: CardPriv1_NOT FOR COPY

This clamp joins OpenBeam/Misumi 1515 extrusions at a 90 degree angle. It is meant for axial and radial loads, it will probably not do a good job for angular loads. The screws (M3 12mm) are off-center by design for two reasons: 1) Make it as small as possible 2) Prevent stress/cracks along the center Additional parts needed:
  • Recommended mounting: 4x M3 12mm
  • Alternative mounting: 2x M3 12mm and 1x M3 8mm
I had problems to print the large rods for Rostock printer on my printbed. So i divided the rod into two parts.

Print two half-rods (130mm) to get a full sized Rostock rod (260mm). Use two M3x10 screws + nuts and screw them together.
Because the Rostock needs 6 rods, you have to print 12 half-rods.

title: Vacuum Bullet for DN50 pipe - hollow shell

description.text:
You've seen the ping pong ball on Mythbusters go faster than the speed of sound and punch a hole in a ping pong bat! ... yea. thought we'd try that one at home.  
The DN40 pipe that I got here in New Zealand was too small for the 40mm ping pong ball. So I ended up using DN50 and of course that was too big for the ping pong ball.  
SOLUTION... print your own...  only not a ball. A hollow shell. The design could be improved upon, its set for 0.3mm thickness wall and depending on your printer a 0.4mm thickness wall will do better. Anyway after trimming the base slightly this fits nicely in the DN50 pipe and is just perfect when the vacuum is released.  
AND IT LOOKS COOL.  
If you release the shell at a wall or hard object it will be destroyed.... and that's where the science begins... just how fast is it going?

comments.text:
nope... I had not seen this one... thanks for the tip. Very interesting.
Youtube had one demo where the ball exceeded the speed of sound but the vacuum was supplemented with pressure from an air compressor. Search for the one where a watermelon is destroyed. On a short Mythbuster vid the guy verbalized "...over 300mph".
Seems like there's something wrong with the ball exceeding the speed of sound in the atmosphere when it is the atmosphere itself which powers that projectile... Wouldn't the air have to push something faster than the air is moving?
comments.author: Terminus
